posts.post_content:
I understand the concept - trap a unit in a pocket of slowed time and make the controller spend mana on getting it out of there (thanks for the explanation Kivati) - but I think it was executed in the wrong way. This would have felt right if it made use of the phase mechanic - something along the lines of "Enchanted creature has Phasing. Whenever enchanted creature phases in, it's controller may pay ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol). If he/she doesn't, enchanted creature phases out."  
  
Anyway, as it is, this card is powerful. It kills your opponents creatures or slows them down a lot, and the return mechanic means that regular [disenchant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=disenchant)s & [naturilize](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=naturilize)s just won't do. Fits control decks nicely, and should definitely see some play in the casual environment.  
Is it too strong? I doubt it, since it was printed in the same set as [Rancor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rancor), and it was common too (but then again, Urza's block was full of overpowered stuff).
posts.html:

This would have felt right if it made use of the phase mechanic - something along the lines of "Enchanted creature has Phasing. Whenever enchanted creature phases in, it's controller may pay . If he/she doesn't, enchanted creature phases out."

Anyway, as it is, this card is powerful. It kills your opponents creatures or slows them down a lot, and the return mechanic means that regular disenchants & naturilizes just won't do. Fits control decks nicely, and should definitely see some play in the casual environment.
Is it too strong? I doubt it, since it was printed in the same set as Rancor, and it was common too (but then again, Urza's block was full of overpowered stuff).

posts.post_content:
re-usable enchantments are VERY dangerous in non-tournament play.  
Wizards should not have made this card's effect so crippling, if it is re-usable.  
Basically, if it's not countered are exiled, it cripples a player's manabase or continually removes any of his creatures - repeatedly. Too strong.

Posted By: reapersaurus (5/9/2010 2:12:19 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Like the spell, though it's more like a black effect. I don't understand what the effect has to do with slow motion as a comcept, or the concept compared to the art, but like the spell nonetheless. Should've been black though, it's more about death and sacrifice.
  
Slow motion should have been a spell that makes your creature either unable to block, attacking with half power or only untapping every other turn, that would've made sense.

Posted By: TheSwarm (8/19/2010 11:32:01 PM)

posts.post_content:
Too few cards are made that involve giving the opponent the option of paying mana to do something about it.  
  
I like the style of gameplay that encourages (kind of feels like DragonBallZ or the Priori Incantatem effect in Harry Potter: have a mana/ki battle to see who can pump more power into the clusterbomb you made on the battlefield, thus gaining control of the game, without actually exhausting yourself into oblivion...unless you at least take out your opponent too)  
  
4x [Daze](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Daze)  
4x [Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak)  
4x [Spell Pierce](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Spell Pierce)  
4x [Slow Motion](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Slow Motion)  
  
  
sounds like a good deck :)
posts.html:

I like the style of gameplay that encourages (kind of feels like DragonBallZ or the Priori Incantatem effect in Harry Potter: have a mana/ki battle to see who can pump more power into the clusterbomb you made on the battlefield, thus gaining control of the game, without actually exhausting yourself into oblivion...unless you at least take out your opponent too)

4x Daze
4x Mana Leak
4x Spell Pierce
4x Slow Motion


sounds like a good deck :)
